bonded adjective
(PEOPLE/ANIMALS)
Add to word list

biology, social science
  specialized People or animals who are bonded have a close connection that makes them want to be together: The two cats left at the vet's were obviously a bonded pair and it would have been cruel to separate them. Because the players spend a lot of time travelling together they are very well bonded.

bonded adjective
(ATOMS)
chemistry
  specialized involving or held together by chemical bonds (= strong forces): An ion is an atom or group of bonded atoms which become negatively or positively charged by losing or gaining one or more electrons. covalently bonded molecules Opposite
non-bonded
More examplesFewer examplesFree radicals are formed when each bonded atom or group takes one of the bonding pair of electrons.The covalently bonded non-metal oxides of phosphorus and sulphur dissolve and react in water to form acidic solutions.This is a simple but effective method for predicting the configuration of bonded atoms about a central atom.A diamond is made up of tetrahedrally bonded carbon atoms.

bonded adjective
(GOODS)
business
  specialized Bonded goods are goods brought from another country on which taxes have not yet been paid, usually kept in a special building until the taxes have been paid; a bonded warehouse is a building for keeping goods like this: Customs and Excise would need to approve the transfer of bonded goods to another site. To prevent traffic jams at ports, it's common for shipments to be moved to bonded warehouses close to the purchaser for a Customs inspection.

US a bonded company has insurance in order to protect its customers if the company has a problem: Get estimates from more than one licensed, bonded, reputable contractor.
UK a bonded travel agency (= company that sells holidays) has insurance to protect its customers if there is a problem with the travel agency or the travel arrangements it has provided: Since 1992 we have operated a fully bonded Travel Agency.
